Hello everybody. All right. Well, let me
just first say that this engineering
task was a technical feat, right? I want
to thank the teams that worked on this
because understanding the magic that
happens behind the technical is really
it's beautiful and it's something I
appreciate and a lot of people don't get
to see what happens behind the scenes
but just think at it holistically on
what this is this is this blaster
there's 600 of them always being tracked
there's a hundred of them always being
rotated in a queue for the guests to
have that continuous flow of people and
then uh on the scenes we're actively
tracking 500 of them where we're getting
the telemetry we're getting the data
We're downloading uh visuals, audios, uh
sounds, everything to the blaster in
real time. So, you think about that. We
have a blaster going through uh 500 of
them all on the same network and we're
also going from the same game just in
different levels, right? So, we're we're
propagating 500 people through the same
game. And these games are vertical
slices. So, they basically repeat the
same thing over and over again. The boss
loops and they're interactive for each
of the scenes. And then whatever the
player does carries on to the next
scene. We push it forward the payload
and that continues on until we get to
the end. So we have that persistence of
scene to scene. And then also on top of
that complexity, we have a mobile app.
We always try to push even further. So
we have the mobile app where we can tap
in when we first come into the gun
itself. There's an FC here. We tap that
in. has all of our um previous times we
played, all of our achievements, all of
our perks, all of our new weapons that
we can do it or even our seasonals. We
have like seasons. Every month we have a

if you if you want to play it with your
ultimate. Start thinking about dynamic
content and that idea. We did it all in
this and in the end of it, it was a lot
of learning, a lot of balls, but
basically it was a technical feat that

All right. So,
so minions being minions, they want to
destroy everything. That's one thing
that I really enjoy about this project
because get to work with minions and
minions are mischievous and they just
destroy everything. So, we wanted to
make sure we destroy everything in all
the levels. So, in the very beginning,
we started using chaos physics. Well,
uh, that worked fine in the very
beginning when we started to scale it
with a lot of players. That didn't work
so much. And we worked with our great
partners at Epic to understand why chaos
wouldn't work. We did custom engines. We
came to the point that the collections
weren't reversible. We couldn't get away
from certain hitches inside of it
because it would cause architecture
change and how chaos works at that time.
This is 5.1. So, we ended up pivoting to
old school techniques. We did pre-baked
destructions. We went to Houdini or
whatever dcc we had and pre-baked it and
then we brought it in that way. That way
we could scale and get rid of all those
destruction uh hitches that we were
seeing. The problem is typical legacy
doing those kind of workflows. You have
artifacts. You have now you have a
skeleton joint to all the different
pieces that you want to break up. You
have to manage those pieces. Those are
all it has a cost to it, right? So even
just a visual fidelity. If you break
something and the vertex is shared
across the joints, you'll get a a screen
stretch, right? Everybody knows what
that looks like. It's horrible. We don't
want that. So, we have to go back and
redo all the models to do that. So, we
we were able to gain a significant
amount of performance by going back to
old school methods. But, we weren't
there yet. The next thing we had to do
was object pooling because in the scene
itself, you think about it, we have all
these players. I think our scene too, we
can have the 40 players at once in that
scene and they're on the travelator. So,
a moving walkway playing the whole time
and they're just sitting there spamming
that fire button. Projectile,
projectile, projectile, explosion,
explosion, collectible, collectible. All
these things are being spawned. So,
what's a big cost that we have? It's uh
construction and deconstruction of all
the actors, right? That is a huge cost
for our uh frame rate and that's
something we had to get rid of. And
because our game never reset, there was
no opportunity to do it. So, if we
started playing with garbage collection,
we could sit there and change the
frequency, we could change the
collection size, we do all that fancy
stuff. And then there's always a point
that we had to dump the garbage and
whoever was on the tracks at that point,
all the reticles would freeze at the
same time. We don't want that. So we had
to uh think very creatively about it. So
we created object pooling. So we redid
the whole architecture inside the engine
to do support object pooling. So every
time we had an asset, we reused it. We
just change the state. So for example,
the blasters were object pulled. Every
time we'd sit there, we'd have maybe 40
blasters in a scene and we'd sit there
and move the player state into those
blasters and they would keep moving
forward as it went out. So, those kind
of techniques really push over the edge
for optimizations. So, I know we spent a
lot of time on doing these hitch dump
hitches that was uh pretty constant. I
think you guys all know about that.
>> Uh and then the last thing we wanted to
do, we still weren't getting there. We
were finally getting our CPU bound, but
our GPU and our fidelity, we were not
getting it because we're pushing, I

the LED walls. That's a lot of pixels of

about we use TSR temporal super
resolution from uh uh the engine. The

and these are the ones that get you in.
We got a huge bush uh uh boost in

layout for the pixels themselves,
they're too far apart, right? So
whenever we would have objects move
across the screen, we start seeing a lot
of ghosting. we start seeing a lot of
ghosting from the previous frames
because TSR takes the previous frames
and use the velocities to go to the next
frames. We started seeing a lot of
blurring across the screen. So, we had
to work with Epic quite a bit and this
is something that's great having great
partners like Epic. They they've came on

because it was above the TSR TSR level
and that causes a problem because of
aliasing. Well, you have all these

you have this really jagged edged

everybody's favorite word sears

All right, so this was the this is
actually fun because I I like networking
quite a bit.
But when you look at all the telemetry
and all the data going in and out the
blaster, you think about just the
structure of the network you need to
have designed for that for all the
different servers to communicate. How do
you orchestrate that? Because the
bandwidth is a problem and latency is a
problem. We don't want to have a a guest
moving blaster back and forth and it
lags across the screen. It doesn't feel
good. If it doesn't feel good, no one's
going to enjoy it. So, we had to set to
be very strategic on our network buffer
because if we slam 500 to 600 blasters
on that network, it gets queued up and
the buffer would overrun and we just
start getting hitches all the time,
right? So, sure, we we created a new
buffer. We use a lot of TQS for all the
inbound, all the different types of data
packets. And so we can have that offload
because you can save a buffet frame by
doing stuff like that, right? So we did
that. Still wasn't enough yet. We're
still slamming so much data into our
servers because every server is getting
all the telemetry. It's like, okay,
well, we just need to strategically
physically separate them with VLANs.
Great. Didn't work enough. We need to do
something else. So one of the cool
things we didn't really talk about too
much um is a digital twin. So, we
actually did do this is actually a
digital twin of the attraction inside of
Unreal, right? So, we know spatially
where you're at with the blaster in the
real world and in the virtual world. So,
we set up a system, a geo fencing. We
just started creating volumes inside the
engine from scene to scene to scene. We
knew exactly where the blaster was. So,
we only need to send all the packets
that were in that that um coordinate
system to that server. So, we didn't
have to send all to the servers. So that
really solved a big problem we had for
network flow.
And the other thing was
typically in multiplayer games because
this is what it is a multiplayer game.
You have a dedicated server. Well
dedicated server wouldn't typically take
all this inflow and spread it out but
the dedicated server is getting slammed
too. So we needed a way to figure it
out. So it's more of a peer-to-peer
network the way we started doing it. We
pass information forward. It all starts
in scene zero, right? And passes it
forward. And as we go through the
cycling of the scene, we would hand it
off player data the next one. And then
before we would exit to the last scene,
we'd send it up to the cloud.
All right. So
the cloud itself, the app, everything in

16. So, I remember the initial servers

there were like 128 cores, and we would
see cores 0 through 15 pegged at like

are in the latest video game consoles.
So, we got a massive performance boost

obviously going for less cores, higher
